awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Network Event Detection with Multistream Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal in network event detection is to detect the existence of a set of nodes over a large network whose observations reflect the occurrence of an unusual event. Existing studies of network event detection have been mainly from two perspectives. The first is data-driven without assuming any underlying statistical model, and is typically applicable to more general data sets, but may not come with performance guarantees. The second perspective is model-driven, with certain statistical distributions (e.g., Gaussian) assumed for the data, and usually comes with performance guarantees, but may be limited to applications where the data fit the model. The goal in this project is to explore a framework for network event detection that unifies a wide range of event detection problems, in which the data are assumed to be governed by some underlying statistical distributions, but is data-driven in the sense that little is assumed a priori about the distributions. The developed detection approaches and statistical tools have a wide range of applications, including fraud detection, clinical trials, medical diagnosis, high-frequency trading, voting irregularity analysis, and network intrusion.

A comprehensive approach to general network event detection problems is developed in this project through the exploration of three thrusts: (i) detection of (unstructured) point events, (ii) detection of graph-based structured events, and (iii) sequential and quickest detection of dynamically evolving graph structures. The performance of the designed tests is characterized in terms of the probability of detection error and the rate at which this error goes to zero. Various fundamental issues are addressed, including non-i.i.d. data streams, as well as the interplay between network size, event size, sample size, and data dimension.

por.por_cntn:
The goal in network event detection is to detect the existence of a set of nodes over a large network whose observations reflect the occurrence of an unusual event. The goal in this project was to explore a framework for network event detection that unifies a wide range of event detection problems. The following are the major research findings from the project:

1. We developed nonparametric approaches for detecting outlier sequences in various settings including anomalous data stream detection, universal outlying sequence detection, and composite outlying data streams. We constructed the generalized likelihood (GL) test based on various distributional distance metrics including the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) distance, Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, and Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) distance. We further developed the bounds on the probability of error and analyzed the asymptotic convergence of the performance as the number of sequences and/or the number of hypotheses grow. We also proposed low time complexity tests and established their consistency. 

2. We investigated the detection of graph-based structured events including the detection of an anomalous interval over a line network, detection of an anomalous disk out of a two-dimensional lattice, and detection of an anomalous rectangle out of a lattice network. We proposed kernel-based tests based on MMD, and characterized sufficient and necessary conditions on the size of candidate anomalous structures in order to guarantee the test consistency. Comparison of sufficient and necessary conditions demonstrates that the proposed test is order-level nearly optimal. 

3. We investigated the quickest detection of a dynamic anomaly in sensor networks, where the anomaly can move across the network via a Markovian trajectory. We constructed a windowed generalized likelihood ratio based algorithm, and established its asymptotic optimality. We also studied the case based on a modification of Lorden's criterion to account for the worst-case trajectory of the anomaly, and established that a mixture-CuSum algorithm with uniform weights is strictly optimal under this criterion. We further posed the problem as a stochastic optimization problem by using a delay metric based on the worst possible path of the anomaly, and proposed a detection rule that is asymptotically optimal as the mean time to false alarm goes to infinity. 

4. We studied the quickest detection of dynamic events over networks, where the goal is to design a sequential algorithm that can detect a "significant" event that has affected no fewer than a predetermined set of nodes. We constructed a Network-CuSum (N-CuSum) algorithm that exploits network structure in a computationally efficient way, and showed that NCuSum is adaptive to unknown propagation dynamics, and first-order asymptotically optimal as the false alarm rate goes to zero. We further considered the distributed setting, and proposed a distributed algorithm based on a novel combination of the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) and average consensus approaches. 

5. We investigated the problem of estimating various distributional distance metrics based on samples including KL divergence, MMD, neural net distances, due to the important roles that these distance metrics play in the event detection problems. We proposed various empirical estimators for these distances, and established the sample complexity bounds for the estimators. We also provided the lower bound on the minimax estimation error and established the optimality of the developed estimators.

6. We explored the sequential sampling algorithms, which have wide applications in event detection to achieve sampling efficiency. We focused on temporal difference (TD) learning algorithm, which evaluates the value function of a given sampling policy, and studied the two time-scale TD with gradient correction (TDC) algorithm. We established the finite-time convergence rate for TDC under Markovian sampling and under either diminishing or constant stepsize, and demonstrated the sample complexity efficiency of such an algorithm in various settings. 

We developed several analysis techniques which can be broadly applicable to signal processing, control, optimization, information theory and statistics problems: (i) a new framework on non-parametric event detection that captures the interplay of the training samples and test samples and their impact on the error decay rate; (ii) new tools to characterize minimax optimal estimators for distributional distance metrics; (iii) new analysis tools to characterize the convergence rate of sequential detection algorithms; and (iv) new techniques to characterize the sample complexity for learning over sequentially sampled data. 
The results and findings of this project have been disseminated to a wide range of researchers in various communities through journal publications, conference presentations and publications, and invited talks and tutorials by the team members.

The students and postdocs working on the project have learned new mathematical techniques in sequential analysis, quickest change detection, sample complexity analysis, stochastic optimization, and  learning schemes over sequentially sampled data, and on the performance analysis of various algorithms applicable to event detection problems. They also had opportunities to present the results at conferences and interact with other researchers in the field.
